issues.title: Draft name needs to conform to IETF pattern
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Draft name should be draft-ietf-mediaman-6838bis - this can wait until we have formally adopted the document.

(Was surprised to see this come out without an -authorname- component)

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Fixed by publishing of draft-ietf-mediaman-6838bis

issues.title: Incorporate -toplevel
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The content of [-toplevel ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-mediaman-toplevel/) needs to be incorporated in 6838bis.
The historical portions can probably be left in the published RFC, which 6838bis will obsolete.

issues.title: Incorporate -suffixes
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The content of [-suffixes ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-mediaman-suffixes/) needs to be incorporated into 6838bis.
The current text is deemed to represent WG consensus, but wordsmithing is expected.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body:
As mentioned briefly at the 121 meeting, there are portions of the suffixes draft that should not be incorporated. 

The [proceedings](https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/121/proceedings) still say "No minutes" but the session recordings are available:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aEgdzv7EsPk
https://meetecho-player.ietf.org/playout/?session=IETF121-MEDIAMAN-20241105-1800

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Just to close the comment on minutes - minutes are now here: https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/121/materials/minutes-121-mediaman-202411051800-01

issues.title: Incorporate -standards-tree
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body: The content of [-standards-tree](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-mediaman-standards-tree/) is deemed to represent rough consensus in the WG, and should be incorporated in 6838bis.

issues.title: Cleanup for "additional information" in media type registration
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
From Paul Libbrecht:

Just a reminder: if we update RFC 6838 then it would be cool to:

*    remove “Macintosh file type code(s)” (which doesn’t exist anymore since MacOSX)
*    add “Windows clipboard flavour” and “macOS Universal Type Identifier” among the additional information fields.

comments.author: polx
alvestrand
comments.body:
The RFC Editors page at https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc6838 seems to not list one. The RFC predates the universal presence of XML formats.

There's an XML format on the I-D page for the last-before-publication I-D: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs/14/

I think either Tony Hansen or John Klensin might have one too.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
OK. So here would be a patch and the resulting XML compared to [the last-before-publication I-D](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs/14/):

In substance:
- replace the suggestion to the MacOS file type by the suggestions for macOS UTIs and Windows clipboard flavor names
- replace the literature entry of MacOS file type (which was 21 y old and whose URL is no longer available, an [archive fetch](https://web.archive.org/web/20080517021842/http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n55381) exists still) by an explanation of the macOS UTIs and windows clipboard flavors.

Is this enough for an inclusion? 
Should this be more text-oriented to be included in a new RFC?
Or should the RFC 6838 be made into a newer document, maybe together with the mediaman release?

thanks in advance.
Paul

* [add-clipboard-flavor-names.patch](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/files/14473152/add-clipboard-flavor-names.patch)
* The resulting XML file is called `.txt` since GitHub considereds XML unsupported (LOL):  [draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs-14.xml.txt](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/files/14473159/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs-14.xml.txt)

comments.author: polx
comments.body: Following the existing pull-requests, I added a pull-request against the current markdown source in the git repo to address the same changes.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Fixed by #17 - new issues may be raised for the topics mentioned in the PR.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
Thank you very much.

> Discussion in Bangkok: Perfectly reasonable to do, worry about whether backfill can be done for older types.

The first step would be to take the official specs of the vendors and back-fill with the content of these.  I am happy to hear about process suggestions.

issues.title: Appeal procedure could be more crisp
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body: The appeal procedure is borrowed from 2026. It may not be the right procedure.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: Murray mentioned this on list https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/XXcfDsT_TSQTZ21pV1oNeLJ5YJw/ and I concur with the sentiment https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/dxJvDOM3IADlrSXhc8sVqGVQiS8/

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Duplicate of #10

issues.title: Grandfathering requirements should apply to all unregistered media-types
issues.author: CxRes
issues.body:
I find that the text in paragraph 2 of Appendix A is only targeting unfaceted subtypes that should be registered as faceted. There are unregistered or improperly registered unfaceted subtypes that might need to re-registered as unfaceted. Such as media-types mentioned in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/issues/6.

This text should therefore RECOMMEND that in all cases where the media-types are unregistered, missing a registration template or have unstructured templates, they should be re-registered if possible.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I suspect the community format process might subsume the grandfathering text, as well as this under 'Standards Tree':

> or in rare cases when registering a grandfathered (see {{grandfather}}) and/or otherwise incomplete registration is in the interest of the Internet community.

issues.title: higher bar for IETF registrations than for external ones?
issues.author: bc-pi
issues.body: please see the thread https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/Wlx2B1k_du8Ths2ojxL4jh7V7JM/

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Discussion in Bangkok:
Yes, this is by design (says Alexey as DE)
We may want a procedure for early registration - the IANABIS WG may be working on this.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Decision in Bangkok: Yes, this is the current rule.
New issue: Should we have an early allocation procedure? (make a placeholder, and get Designated Expert review)? (this applies also to other organizations) (Relevant: RFC 7120)
New issue: Should we talk about what we expect from other standards organizations in maturity before they (allocate/register) names?

issues.title: can "Person for further info" be an IETF WG / mailing list?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Some IETF specs (ex: [RC9594](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9594.html) use an IETF WG name and mailing list for the Person and Email, but most do not (I saw one that referred IANA to the Editor's Addresses). I would like this document to either tell WGs explicitly "DO THAT" or "DON'T DO THAT" please.

WGs come and go and hopefully live shorter lives than people, but IETF mailing lists can last a pretty long time.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Personally, I'm skeptical of MLs as change controllers.
I believe the IESG (or successor bodies) will live longer than most WGs.
Mailing lists are frequently closed when the WG is gone and the maintainer gets tired of dealing with the spam.
Also, mailing lists have no built-in decision procedure - how can you tell if a mailing list with 100+ mostly silent members agree on something?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
This isn't about change controllers.  There are three relevant fields in the template:

*   Person and email address to contact for further information:
*   Author:  
*   Change controller: 

Recent registrations that I've created use "IETF" for the last and the document authors for the first two.  Rohan is interested in whether the WG mailing list is a better place to point people for the first (I think).  I'd also ask about the second for WG products.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Yes, as Martin said I am referring to the first "Person & email address to
contact for further information:"
thanks,
-rohan


On Mon, Nov 18, 2024, 14:43 Martin Thomson ***@***.***> wrote:

> This isn't about change controllers. There are three relevant fields in
> the template:
>
>    - Person and email address to contact for further information:
>    - Author:
>    - Change controller:
>
> Recent registrations that I've created use "IETF" for the last and the
> document authors for the first two. Rohan is interested in whether the WG
> mailing list is a better place to point people for the first (I think). I'd
> also ask about the second for WG products.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/issues/9#issuecomment-2484287667>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AADSQPSLILTZSPKQPVI4TET2BJUS3AVCNFSM6AAAAABSAREKHCVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZDIOBUGI4DONRWG4>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: OK, changed the title. In that case, I think an IETF (or other org's) mailing list makes sense; it would be the change controller's responsibility to update the field when a mailing list shuts down.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
@mnot as the author do you want to weigh in on this? If you are amenable, I'll send you a short PR. Maybe instead of "Person and email address to contact for further information", it would be clearer: "Contact name and email address for further information". Then the text could explain that Contact name is an IETF/IRTF mailing list if the work is a product of the IETF, or the name/email of a human person otherwise?

And you might as well give your views about the "Author" field as well.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I think it's reasonable, but keeping it up to date requires action, and it's often not clear who the action holder is. Somewhat related, I'd like to do some work on clarifying what the responsibilities and powers of a designated expert are.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Discussion in Bangkok:
WGs don't last forever, so if we accept that, we need a procedure to update the pointer when they are defunct.
(The same applies to people, but on a longer timescale)
Should we have a fallback pointer? A procedure to get the fallback, depending on change controller?
Fallback pointer may be change controller pointer.
Resolution: Continue discussion in issue.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Formally, I think the change controller needs to be responsible for updating the "Person to contact for further info".
I don't like encumbering the DE with too much proactive responsibility - we might ask IANABIS whether they should maintain a database of contact addresses and take the responsibility of flushing out contacts that don't work any more.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
Assuming the media-types mailing-list is still alive, isn't the procedure used in the media-type declaration (but with a different template) to post an actualization of the contact-addresses at the media-types mailing-list then handling by directors the right method?

The same "authority inspection" worries are concerned here, or? And making it transparent is publicly important for sure.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: This (update procedure) seems to be a more generic question, pertaining to section 6.1 "change procedures". I filed #21 to track that question.

issues.title: What's the correct appeals procedure for DE decisions?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
From Murray Kucherawy (mailing list Nov 8):

RFC 6838 Section 5.3 creates an appeal process by referencing RFC 2026 Section 6.5.4 and saying that appeals go to the IESG.  That specific part of RFC 2026 suggest the appeal process being established appears to me to boil down to:

* the appeal goes to the IESG, and there's no escalation available past that
* the appeal must provide adequate detail
* the appeal must be filed within two months of the DE's decision
* the IESG has discretion to process the appeal however it wants
* the IESG has to complete its review and deliver its decision in a reasonable amount of time

...or at least that's how I read it.  Maybe I'm being too pedantic but I also note that RFC 2026 Section 6.5.4 is subordinate to Section 6.5, which says that it (and its subsections) apply to decisions that are made as part of the standards process using consensus development, and decisions of a DE do not meet that definition.  It doesn't look to me like 6.5.4 was meant to be referenced or incorporated in this way.

I suggest this is something the WG should review and decide whether it wants to keep this as-is or perhaps say something more explicit and crisp.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Notes:
- So far we have no appeals (AFAIK), so we don't know if the process works.
- I believe the choice to point to 6.5.4 directly was deliberately done as "we are reusing the appeals process for a different purpose than what it was originally written for"
- 6.5.4 doesn't specify the appeals chain; I believe the idea was that the response to an appeal under 6.5.4 would be an IESG action, which could then be appealed using the appeals chain in 6.5.2.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: This may be an IANABIS problem.

issues.title: Acknowledgements
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Including authors of incorporated drafts

issues.title: You might consider adding some override here, incase the existing change controller is not responsive.
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
You might consider adding some override here, incase the existing change controller is not responsive.

issues.title: If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.

For example: Do not attempt to register top levels wheihc are pointers ....

_Originally posted by @OR13 in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/12#discussion_r1941490850_

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
The "negative criteria" section was added after a discussion on the list where someone suggested a top-level type that would register by implication some huge number of other entities (I think it was, among other things, going to have a separate media type for integers).

We concluded that such a thing would be a Bad Idea, and tried to find some way of incorporating that into the RFC. The "negative criteria" were the result.

We could reformulate it in such a way that either the intro says "the registration process SHOULD/MUST reject attempts to register top level types that satisfies the following criteria", or that each criterion starts off with "You SHOULD NOT attempt to register ....."

I think choosing between these forms is editor's privillege.

issues.title: Update Media Type registry to clearer indicate which media types do have RTP payload formats
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
With the approval and imminent publication of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-avtcore-rtp-payload-registry/ there no longer separate registry for which media types are RTP payload formats. Although if going through the media types registrations themselves one can determine if they represent RTP payload formats. Please note that some are both file formats and RTP payload formats. Thus, I would request that when updating the media type procedures and registry one should consider some clarifications to help identify media types that have RTP payload formats.

1. I would suggest that one add a column in the media types registry for each entry to indicate those that have RTP payload formats. 
2. Secondly there is the question if one like to convert the implicit indicator in the encoding information, that some but not all framed encodings are RTP, and rather have an explicit field in the registration template to say: Media Type has an RTP payload format.

issues.title: Should the bucket format parameters from RFC 6381 be noted as something to consider?
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc6381/ defines parameters that are used to describe further properties of like codec capabilities of what is included in file formats that are so called bucket types, like the ISO based media file formats. 

Should there be a reference to these parameters and the consideration in the media type registry to ensure that this aspect is not forgotten. I can see that this could be either part of the relevant media top levels that commonly have these, or possibly under the parameter encoding section.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: I would also note that RFC 8088 do comment some other parameters that RTP payload format has used with the same definition over multiple media types used to register RTP payload format. I don't know if these needs to be noted or referenced that they exist to help registrants to include them if applicable.

issues.title: Instructions for other SDOs on how to maintain registrations
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The procedures for IANA to check IETF work on updating specs is working reasonably well.
There are no corresponding procedures for other SDOs. They should be advised that they need to have one.

issues.title: More detailed change procedures?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Section 6.1 "Change procedures" is pretty short.
In particular, it doesn't say much about:
- Who can make changes (presumably "change controller")
- How one can make changes if change controller is unavailable or unresponsive
- When a change controller is supposed to make changes (for instance "if a listed contact point changes"?)

More text may be needed.

issues.title: change media-types@iana.org to media-types@ietf.org
issues.author: anewton1998
issues.body:
6838 lists media-types@iana.org as the email to send registrations. However, this is just a forwarder to media-types@ietf.org. I suggest skipping the forwarder and changing the email address in 6838bis to media-types@ietf.org.

Also, it might be helpful to have an informative reference to the [list archive](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/media-types/).

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: We might want to ask IANABIS to formulate a general policy on IETF-related review list addresses, if we don't have one.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Sent off a quick note today. https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ianabis/IneNOsZleuL7pnJ-oeSOf09_4D4/

issues.title: Community format change controller
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Standards tree says:

> The "owner" of a media type registered in the standards tree is assumed to be the standards-related organization itself.

What should it be for community formats?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Should we require the community to name a representative or representative organization?
I would assume that the normal case is change controller = registrant.

issues.title: Should coordination with previous registrar of +-suffixed types be required?
issues.author: bc-pi
issues.body:
It is extremely frustrating and belittling to feel that perfectly reasonable input is being ignored. 

> This is text that I was explicitly objecting to at the previous in-person meeting and that I was under the impression that the author of this PR agreed as did at least one of the DEs.

_Originally posted by @bc-pi in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/14#discussion_r2000685271_

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/df706dda-2b9e-454c-93fa-cca1639b5f4b)

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
The chairs directed the editors to incorporate the current text from -suffixes without changes to the semantics.
We have noted that this is a point on which there is a need for further discussion before declaring consensus.
I didn't find the previous issue filed on the subject, so I changed the subject of this one, and will follow up.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body:
> The chairs directed the editors to incorporate the current text from -suffixes without changes to the semantics.

Was that before or after the WG meeting in Vancouver?

issues.title: Negative criteria repetitiveness
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Negative criteria says roughly the same thing four times:

* A top-level type is not a pointer into another registration space that offers duplicate registrations for existing media types. Example: a top-level type of 'oid', leading to types of the form oid/nnnnn, where nnn is an OID (Object Identifier) designating a specific media format,

* A top-level type MUST NOT be defined for the mapping of other protocol elements to media types. For example, while there may be some merit to a mapping from media types to URIs, e.g. in the context of RDF (Resource Description Framework), there is very limited merit in a reverse mapping, and even less merit in creating a top-level type for such a mapping. The same applies to other protocol elements such as file extensions or URI schemes. The recommended solution in case a mapping is needed is to choose a single type/subtype and put the additional information in an appropriately named parameter. As an example, information on a file extension '.dcat' can be encoded as 'application/octet-string; filename=foo.dcat'.

* Media types are not a general type system. A top-level type MUST NOT be defined if its main or only purpose is to map other type systems, e.g. in programming languages or ontologies.

* A new top-level type SHOULD NOT generate aliases for existing widely used types or subtypes.

There has to be a more efficient and friendly way to convey this; using bullet points implies that they're four different things, and they're not.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: I believe this text was prompted by four different attempted registrations that were a Bad Idea..... we may want to wordsmith this to a single "don't ask for a top level type when it's not appropriate" and have the list of inappropriate registrations as examples.

issues.title: use of 2119 terms
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The spec uses MUST/MAY/SHOULD throughout to indicate registration requirements, not interoperability requirements.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
In procedural documents like this, it seems that "interoperability" is the abillity for the parties to get their job done by conforming to procedure - "interoperability" between registrar and registry in this case.

I don't want to try to come up with an alternative terminology just because it isn't a computer protocol.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: That's not my understanding of current IETF usage. We should clarify with the IESG.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: It is consistent with 2119, which uses MUST to refer to its own requirements. What later guidance has been issued?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Timely:
  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/statement-iesg-statement-on-clarifying-the-use-of-bcp-14-key-words/

I read that as discouraging such use, but I can see an argument that it doesn't explicitly address this case.

issues.title: Incorporate 'font' top-level type
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: ... from RFC 8081.

comments.author: svgeesus
comments.body: So would that contain all of RFC 8081, thus obsoleting it, or is it just a mention in a list of top level types?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: We can't obsolete 8081 because it contains the subtype registrations, so I suspect it would be a short section and then a reference to 8081 for details.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
I don't think the registration procedure should attempt to be a complete listing of the registry (for obvious reasons - the registry is going to expand over time, the procedure can't reflect the future).

8081 is already referenced in [RFC 9694's history section](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9694.html#section-3). I don't see a good argument for treating it more specially than that. (PR #12 noted that it omitted the history section, and made a note about whether or not we should change that, but we don't have an open issue for that.)

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Well, we could omit _all_ top-level type descriptions from this document...

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
... and say "these are registered by 6838-no-bis? Works for me :-)
(unless we find that the old registrations are incomplete and need to be modified, in which case there needs to be an "updates to existing registrations" section ... the registration rules say that they need to be defined by a standards-track document, which is satisfied by 6838 or 6838bis as the WG wills it.)

comments.author: svgeesus
comments.body:
> 8081 is already referenced in [RFC 9694's history section](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9694.html#section-3). I don't see a good argument for treating it more specially than that.

I do.

The existing 8081 reference merely uses it as an _example_ on how to add a new top-level type.

As a currently-existing top-level type, though, `font/` (and `model/`) should be listed the same as the other top-level types

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Hmm. I think we could remove the top-level type definitions _if_ there were a registry specifically for them, but there's not. Thoughts?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Well, https://www.iana.org/assignments/top-level-media-types/top-level-media-types.xhtml looks awfully like the registry created by 9694, so I guess we have one...

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Aha! I didn't see that linked from the media types registry...

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I think someone would need to go through and verify that none of the text regarding these in 6838 was unique.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Issue #29 created. With that, I think we can close this issue as "no action needed" (on the assumption that -bis won't have a list of top level types with descriptions in it).

issues.title: Applicability statements
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
> It is expected that applicability statements for particular applications will be published from time to time in the IETF, recommending implementation of, and support for, media types that have proven particularly useful in those contexts.

Really?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Much has been expected of applicability statements, but little has been done about them....

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I'm leaning towards just removing this.

issues.title: Review and maybe delete old top level type descriptions
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The old top level descriptions (text, application and so on) are referenced in the IANA registry at https://www.iana.org/assignments/top-level-media-types/top-level-media-types.xhtml as being defined in RFC 2026.

Their description is copied in the text of RFC 6838, and so far in 6838bis.

It would make for a shorter document if we could delete them and just say that 2026 is the normative reference for them, but before doing that, we need to verify that there are no changes to the description between 2026 and 6838 that we want to make normative.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I had a fairly quick look through them all and am comfortable removing this text, which is largely duplicative.

However, we should make it more discoverable, by:
- Linking to the top-level types registry both in the draft and in the subtypes registry
- Specifying section numbers in the top-level types registry

issues.title: Standards tree duplicates requirements and text
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
The 'standards tree' section outlines requirements about publication and also specifies process for handling these registrations. Both of these are covered in other sections.

Should we:

1.  move all standards-tree requirements under the standards tree section (possibly removing duplicative text and requirements elsewhere), or
2. move these things out of the standards tree section into the requirements and process sections (possibly with appropriate references)?

I'm leaning towards (2).

issues.title: Vendor tree for community formats
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
> Note that industry consortia as well as non-commercial entities that do not qualify as recognized standards-related organizations can register media types in the vendor tree.

Can this be removed now that we have the community formats process?

pulls.title: Add toplevel
pulls.author: mnot
pulls.body:
- omitted IANA instructions as it appears they'll be published in a separate RFC
- omitted history and introduction; should discuss whether they are necessary and how to incorporate if so

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: After discussion in Bangkok

```suggestion
* Top-level types can help humans with understanding and debugging. Therefore, evaluating how a new top-level type helps humans understand types may be crucial.
```

If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.

For example: Do not attempt to register top levels which are pointers ....

```suggestion
* A top-level type MUST NOT be defined for the mapping of other protocol elements to media types. For example, while there may be some merit to a mapping from media types to URIs, e.g. in the context of RDF (Resource Description Framework), there is very limited merit in a reverse mapping, and even less merit in creating a top-level type for such a mapping. The same applies to other protocol elements such as file extensions or URI schemes. The recommended solution in case a mapping is needed is to choose a single type/subtype and put the additional information in an appropriately named parameter. As an example, information on a file extension '.dcat' can be encoded as 'application/octet-string; filename=foo.dcat'.
```

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Bangkok: Hold for more discussion online

reviews.author: msporny
reviews.body:
LGTM as the Editor of the structured suffixes WG draft, thanks for merging in the structured suffixes text into 6838bis, @mnot.

I presume this ends my work on structured suffixes and the hand off to you is complete. Let me know if that's not true.

comments.body: You might consider adding some override here, incase the existing change controller is not responsive.

Since the above language restricts structured suffixes to a single '+', perhaps this line can be removed entirely?

```suggestion
```
This (power to deny given to first registrant) always worried me too.
This is text that I was explicitly objecting to at the previous in-person meeting and that I was under the impression that the author of this PR agreed as did at least one of the DEs.
https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/121/materials/minutes-121-mediaman-202411051800-01

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/0uFNmOANPD-vECTWzsampRvKGtc/ 
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/gipt2Qv0uKw2ZBN97Jo4Mddnw_I/
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/media-types/eM5ljPWq_fFaz9Mrt-vBHJi8fXE/

I don't remember and/or can't find at the moment all the right conversations. But I am questioning the cost/value of such participation at all.
this too https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/14/files#r2000685271
@OR13 could you open that as a separate issue?

pulls.title: Clean-up for "additional information"
pulls.author: polx
pulls.body:
Following https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/issues/5 this commit changes the additional information to:
- remove the Macintosh 4-byte identifiers (not in use since decades) and
- replaces them by the optional inclusion of clipboard flavour names

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
> Create a corresponding issue, please.

never mind...

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Discussion in Bangkok: Perfectly reasonable to do, worry about whether backfill can be done for older types.
We would like to put in stuff that might be in use for other platforms (iOS, Android) if they exist and are different.

comments.author: CxRes
comments.body: Should we open a new issue for backfills?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Yes, do that in the "procedures" repo, which is intended for procedural issues that do not involve changes to 6838bis.

comments.author: polx
comments.body: Issue [#7 of procedures](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/issues/7) is opened. Thanks.

```suggestion
* Windows clipboard name (a string), if it makes sense to exchange media of this type through user-triggered exchange mechanisms such as copy-and-paste or drag-and-drop on Microsoft Windows and related platforms (see {{windowsClipboardNames}} for definitions and syntax).
```
